info: Which of the following is not a part of the simple approach to build a good chart?
What is the first aspect of the Science of How We See?
option_2: We see first what stands out
option_3: We see only a few things at once
option_4: We seek meaning and make connections

info: What is the second aspect of the Science of How We See?
option_1: We see first what stands out
option_3: We seek meaning and make connections
option_4: We see only a few things at once

option_1: titles aren't usually the first thing a chart reader sees. 2) Rather
option_2: they are clues to help find the meaning that emerges when looking at the chart

info: What is the third aspect of the Science of How We See?
option_1: We see only a few things at once
option_3: We seek meaning and make connections
option_4: We see first what stands out

info: A good guide is that with more than _ to _ variables or elements- individual meaning begins to fade
What is the fourth aspect of the Science of How We See?
option_1: We seek meaning and make connections
option_3: We see only a few things at once

info: 1) Anything that stands out becomes part of the narrative we're trying to form 2) What's presented becomes a crucial factor in the success of the chart
What is the fifth aspect of the Science of How We See?
option_1: We rely on conventions and metaphors
option_2: We see only a few things at once

info: Which two questions need to be considered before creating a visualisation? 1) Is the information conceptual or data-driven? 2) Am I declaring something or exploring something? 3) Am I presenting to key stakeholders? 4) Who will evaluate the chart?
